bibl.title: Letter fragment from Henry Rose Carter to Emma Coleman Carter, May 11, 1890

div1.p: Carter expresses his fear that yellow fever will be a problem in the Yucatan during the upcoming season.

div1.head: Letter fragment from Henry Rose Carter to Emma Coleman Carter, May 11, 1890
div1.opener:
MARINE HOSPITAL SERVICE
1798 * U. S. * 1871
U. S. Marine-Hospital Service,
DISTRICT OF THE GULF,
Port of U.S. Gulf Quarantine, Surgeon's Office.
Biloxi, Miss.
May 11, 1890.
My Dear Mother:
div1.p:
My face is perfectly free from
pain although there are still two (maybe 3)
small pieces of bone to come out still as I feel well
& am in no pain I don't care any anything a-
bout the dead bone, especially as I got rid of
three teeth. I have only 8 more thank Goodness.
No ships as yet, I see however-most unfortunate
it is too - that there is Y. F. in Yucatan. Just now
there is a R R. building from Merida to Progresso
on which practically all the labor is from La. & Miss &
Tex. Also the main communication from that
country to this is per six eight schooners that run, 6
to Pearl River (per Ship Island) & two to Pascagoula
They are only from 4 days upwards on the trip &
many of these laborers came back in them
as stowaways-. i.e. pay 25 cents for the passage.

you can see what a source of danger this will be
if the fever gets violent & there is a panicky exodus.
However I am here to work & if work & anxiety
comes I need not be disappointed.

My cook & Laundress have come &, although I have
one man sick, we are getting along, About 10 days more
work will only leave us the ordinary routine
Very different from last year when there
was always extra work for 10 or 12 men.

I have been studying to some extent for my exami-
nation. To my mind this is folly-utter folly- One
examination four years after entrance is
right & good & serves to winnow out those that
are trifling & prevents the younger men from
neglecting their profession. After that it seems
to me that unless a man can be trusted to attend
to his work & his profession he ought to be court-
martialed & cashiered. However it is Law not
Regulation. I suppose I will come on in June - most proba-
bly about the last part. It is possible that it may be in
July however.

We are all well- rather better than usual &, having
killed a pig yesterday- fattened on shares with the Light House -yester-
day in a state of abundance & luxury. Maud, the stew
ards little girl, is sick but will soon be well I think. Ed is
I have read almost all of Drummond's book & have enjoyed
it. It is a very remarkable one unlike anything I have seen before.
